name: Sun
subtitle: The Star at the Center
description: The blazing heart of our solar system, source of light and life.

story.headline: Sun: The Solar Engine
story.introduction: The Sun is a G-type main-sequence star that sits at the center of our solar system. Its immense gravity holds the planets, asteroids, and comets in orbit, while its energy drives Earth's climate and sustains life.

sections.title: A Giant Ball of Plasma
sections.content: The Sun is composed mostly of hydrogen and helium. Through nuclear fusion in its core, it converts hydrogen into helium, releasing vast amounts of energy as light and heat. Every second, the Sun fuses about 600 million tons of hydrogen.

sections.title: Layers of the Sun
sections.content: The Sun has several layers: the core (where fusion happens), the radiative and convective zones, the visible photosphere, the chromosphere, and the outer corona. The corona, visible during a total solar eclipse, is hotter than the surface and extends millions of kilometers into space.

sections.title: Solar Activity
sections.content: The Sun's surface is dynamic, with sunspots, solar flares, and coronal mass ejections. These phenomena can affect space weather, impacting satellites, communications, and even power grids on Earth. The Sun follows an 11-year cycle of activity, from solar minimum to solar maximum.

Sun is halfway through its main-sequence life

name: Mercury
subtitle: The Swift Messenger
description: The smallest planet and closest to the Sun, a world of extremes.

story.headline: Mercury: The Sun's Scorched Companion
story.introduction: Mercury, the smallest planet in our solar system and closest to the Sun, experiences the most extreme temperature variations of any planet. This ancient, cratered world races around the Sun faster than any other planet, completing its orbit in just 88 Earth days.

sections.title: A World of Extremes
sections.content: Mercury's proximity to the Sun creates wild temperature swings—from 430°C on the sunlit side to -180°C on the dark side. Without a substantial atmosphere to retain heat, Mercury demonstrates the most extreme temperature variations in the solar system. Despite being closest to the Sun, it's not the hottest planet (Venus holds that title).

sections.title: Ancient Cratered Surface
sections.content: Mercury's surface resembles our Moon, heavily scarred by billions of years of meteorite impacts. The Caloris Basin, one of the largest impact craters in the solar system, spans 1,550 km across. With virtually no atmosphere to erode these features, Mercury preserves a 4-billion-year record of solar system bombardment.

sections.title: Magnetic Mystery
sections.content: Surprisingly, Mercury has a global magnetic field despite its small size—a puzzle for planetary scientists. This magnetic field, though only 1% as strong as Earth's, suggests the planet has a large iron core that remains partially molten. Mercury's iron core makes up about 85% of the planet's radius, the largest proportion of any planet.

name: Venus
subtitle: Earth's Evil Twin
description: A hellish world hidden beneath toxic clouds, the hottest planet in our solar system.

story.headline: Venus: Beauty Concealing Inferno
story.introduction: Venus, named after the Roman goddess of love and beauty, is anything but hospitable. Beneath its brilliant appearance as the brightest object in our night sky lies a hellish world with crushing atmospheric pressure, sulfuric acid clouds, and surface temperatures hot enough to melt lead.

sections.title: The Runaway Greenhouse
sections.content: Venus is the hottest planet in our solar system with surface temperatures averaging 462°C—hot enough to melt lead. This extreme heat results from a runaway greenhouse effect: thick clouds of carbon dioxide trap solar radiation, creating an oven-like environment. The atmospheric pressure at the surface is 92 times that of Earth, equivalent to being 900 meters underwater.

sections.title: Toxic Atmosphere
sections.content: Venus's atmosphere is 96.5% carbon dioxide with clouds of sulfuric acid. These clouds reflect sunlight brilliantly, making Venus the brightest planet in our sky. The upper atmosphere features winds exceeding 360 km/h, circling the planet in just four Earth days—a phenomenon called super-rotation that scientists are still working to fully understand.

sections.title: Backward Rotation
sections.content: Venus rotates backward (retrograde) compared to most planets, and extremely slowly—one Venusian day lasts 243 Earth days, longer than its year of 225 Earth days. This means the Sun rises in the west and sets in the east. Scientists theorize a massive ancient collision may have flipped Venus upside down or tipped it over.

Venera 7 makes first soft landing on Venus

name: Earth
subtitle: The Blue Marble
description: Our home planet, a unique oasis of life in the cosmos.

story.headline: Earth: The Only Known Harbor of Life
story.introduction: In the vast cosmic ocean, Earth stands as the only known world that harbors life. This blue marble, suspended in a sunbeam, has nurtured billions of species over 4.5 billion years.

sections.title: Formation and Early History
sections.content: Earth formed approximately 4.54 billion years ago from the accretion of dust and gas in the early solar system. Within its first billion years, life emerged in the primordial oceans, setting the stage for an extraordinary evolutionary journey.

sections.title: The Water World
sections.content: 71% of Earth's surface is covered by water, making it unique among rocky planets. Our oceans regulate climate, produce oxygen through phytoplankton, and host ecosystems of stunning diversity—from coral reefs to deep-sea trenches.

sections.title: The Atmosphere
sections.content: Earth's atmosphere is composed of 78% nitrogen and 21% oxygen, with trace amounts of other gases. This protective blanket shields us from harmful solar radiation and maintains temperatures suitable for liquid water—the essence of life as we know it.

name: Mars
subtitle: The Red Planet
description: A cold desert world and humanity's next frontier.

story.headline: Mars: Humanity's Next Great Adventure
story.introduction: Mars, the fourth planet from the Sun, beckons humanity with its rusty red surface and tantalizing hints of a watery past. This world, half the size of Earth, holds secrets about planetary evolution and the potential for life beyond our home.

sections.title: The Red Landscape
sections.content: Mars' distinctive red color comes from iron oxide (rust) covering its surface. The planet features the largest volcano in the solar system, Olympus Mons, standing 21 km tall—nearly three times the height of Mount Everest. Valles Marineris, a canyon system stretching over 4,000 km, dwarfs the Grand Canyon.

sections.title: Water and Ice
sections.content: Evidence of ancient river valleys, lake beds, and minerals that form in water suggests Mars once had a thicker atmosphere and liquid water on its surface. Today, water exists as ice in polar caps and underground reservoirs. Recent discoveries show seasonal flows that might indicate briny liquid water.

sections.title: Exploration and Future
sections.content: Robotic explorers—from Viking landers to Perseverance rover—have revolutionized our understanding of Mars. The planet's thin atmosphere (95% CO₂) and cold temperatures (-63°C average) present challenges for human exploration, but NASA and private companies are planning crewed missions for the 2030s.

timeline.event: Perseverance rover lands in Jezero Crater

name: Asteroid Belt
subtitle: The Scattered Remnants
description: A vast ring of rocky debris between Mars and Jupiter, remnants of planetary formation.

story.headline: The Asteroid Belt: Echoes of Creation
story.introduction: Between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter lies a vast ring of rocky debris—the asteroid belt. This cosmic junkyard contains millions of asteroids ranging from dust particles to dwarf planets, representing the building blocks that never coalesced into a planet, disrupted by Jupiter's immense gravitational influence.

sections.title: A Failed Planet
sections.content: The asteroid belt occupies the region where a planet might have formed, but Jupiter's powerful gravity prevented these rocky fragments from coalescing. Despite popular depictions, the belt is mostly empty space—asteroids are separated by vast distances, and spacecraft routinely pass through without incident. The total mass of all asteroids combined is less than 4% of the Moon's mass.

sections.title: Diverse Worlds
sections.content: Asteroids vary tremendously in composition and size. C-type (carbonaceous) asteroids are the most common, rich in carbon and water ice. S-type (silicaceous) asteroids contain silicate minerals and nickel-iron. M-type asteroids are metallic, possibly the exposed cores of destroyed protoplanets. The largest object, Ceres, is 940 km in diameter and classified as a dwarf planet with a possible subsurface ocean.

sections.title: Windows to the Past
sections.content: Asteroids preserve pristine material from the solar system's formation 4.6 billion years ago. Studying them provides insights into planetary formation and the conditions of the early solar system. Some asteroids may have delivered water and organic compounds to early Earth, potentially seeding life. NASA's OSIRIS-REx mission successfully returned samples from asteroid Bennu in 2023.

timeline.event: NEAR Shoemaker lands on asteroid Eros
Dawn mission launches to Vesta and Ceres

name: Jupiter
subtitle: King of the Planets
description: A massive gas giant with dozens of moons.

story.headline: Jupiter: The Giant Guardian
story.introduction: Jupiter reigns as the largest planet in our solar system, a gas giant with a mass greater than all other planets combined. Its powerful gravity has shaped the architecture of our cosmic neighborhood and may have protected Earth from catastrophic impacts.

sections.title: The Great Red Spot
sections.content: Jupiter's most iconic feature is the Great Red Spot, a massive anticyclonic storm larger than Earth that has raged for at least 350 years. Winds in this storm reach speeds of 432 km/h. Recent observations show it's shrinking, though it remains one of the most powerful storms in the solar system.

sections.title: A Miniature Solar System
sections.content: Jupiter has 95 known moons, forming a miniature solar system. The four largest—Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto—were discovered by Galileo in 1610. Europa's subsurface ocean makes it one of the most promising places to search for extraterrestrial life. Io is the most volcanically active body in the solar system.

sections.title: Composition and Structure
sections.content: Jupiter is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium, similar to the Sun. Beneath its colorful cloud bands lies a vast ocean of metallic hydrogen under immense pressure. At the core, temperatures may reach 24,000°C. Jupiter's powerful magnetic field is 20,000 times stronger than Earth's.

timeline.event: Voyager 1 reveals active volcanoes on Io
JUICE mission launches to study icy moons

name: Saturn
subtitle: The Ringed Jewel
description: A gas giant famous for its spectacular ring system.

story.headline: Saturn: Lord of the Rings
story.introduction: Saturn captivates with the most spectacular ring system in the solar system. This gas giant, the second-largest planet, has fascinated humanity since ancient times and continues to reveal surprises about planetary formation, moon systems, and the potential for life in unexpected places.

sections.title: The Magnificent Rings
sections.content: Saturn's rings span 282,000 km in diameter but are remarkably thin—sometimes less than 10 meters thick. Composed of billions of particles ranging from dust grains to house-sized chunks of ice and rock, these rings are thought to be remnants of comets, asteroids, or shattered moons. The rings are divided into several main groups (A, B, C, D, E, F, G) with gaps like the Cassini Division carved by gravitational resonances with Saturn's moons.

sections.title: A Stormy Giant
sections.content: Like Jupiter, Saturn is a gas giant composed mainly of hydrogen and helium. Winds in Saturn's upper atmosphere reach 1,800 km/h—among the fastest in the solar system. Saturn features a persistent hexagonal storm at its north pole, a unique atmospheric phenomenon with sides longer than Earth's diameter. The planet's famous golden hue comes from ammonia crystals in its upper atmosphere.

sections.title: Titan and Enceladus
sections.content: Saturn's 146 known moons include two worlds of exceptional interest. Titan, larger than Mercury, has a thick atmosphere and hydrocarbon lakes—the only known surface liquids beyond Earth. Enceladus, an icy moon, shoots geysers of water vapor into space from a subsurface ocean, making it a prime candidate in the search for life. Both moons are targets for future missions.

timeline.event: Pioneer and Voyager spacecraft fly by
Cassini ends mission with Saturn plunge

name: Uranus
subtitle: The Tilted Ice Giant
description: An ice giant rotating on its side with a mysterious blue-green hue.

story.headline: Uranus: The Sideways World
story.introduction: Uranus, the seventh planet from the Sun, is an oddball in many ways. This ice giant rotates on its side, likely the result of a massive ancient collision, making its seasons the most extreme in the solar system. Its pale cyan color and frigid temperatures make it one of the coldest planets despite not being the most distant.

sections.title: Tilted on Its Side
sections.content: Uranus has an axial tilt of 98 degrees, meaning it essentially orbits the Sun on its side. This extreme tilt causes radical seasonal variations—each pole experiences 42 years of continuous sunlight followed by 42 years of darkness. Scientists believe a massive collision with an Earth-sized object early in the solar system's history knocked Uranus sideways, forever changing its orientation.

sections.title: Ice Giant Composition
sections.content: Unlike Jupiter and Saturn, Uranus is classified as an ice giant. While hydrogen and helium make up its atmosphere, the planet's interior contains 'ices' of water, methane, and ammonia under extreme pressure. Methane in the upper atmosphere absorbs red light, giving Uranus its distinctive cyan color. Below the atmosphere lies a slushy mantle of water, methane, and ammonia surrounding a small rocky core.

sections.title: Rings and Moons
sections.content: Uranus has 13 faint rings discovered in 1977, composed of dark particles. The planet has 27 known moons, mostly named after Shakespearean characters. Miranda, one of Uranus's moons, has a bizarre, fractured surface with towering cliffs and varied terrain, suggesting a violent past of breaking apart and reassembling.

name: Neptune
subtitle: The Windy Blue Giant
description: The most distant planet with the fastest winds in the solar system.

story.headline: Neptune: The Storm-Tossed Giant
story.introduction: Neptune, the eighth and most distant planet from the Sun, is a world of supersonic winds and mysterious dark storms. This deep blue ice giant was the first planet discovered through mathematical prediction rather than direct observation, and continues to surprise scientists with its dynamic atmosphere and intriguing moon system.

sections.title: The Windiest Planet
sections.content: Despite being the farthest planet from the Sun and receiving 900 times less solar energy than Earth, Neptune has the fastest winds in the solar system, reaching speeds up to 2,100 km/h—faster than the speed of sound on Earth. These supersonic winds power massive storm systems including the Great Dark Spot, similar to Jupiter's Great Red Spot. Scientists are still puzzled by what drives such powerful winds on a planet so far from the Sun's heat.

sections.title: Blue Beauty
sections.content: Neptune's striking azure blue color comes from methane in its atmosphere, which absorbs red wavelengths of light and reflects blue. Recent studies suggest an unknown component may contribute to its deeper blue hue compared to Uranus. Like Uranus, Neptune is an ice giant with a slushy mantle of water, methane, and ammonia ices surrounding a rocky core.

sections.title: Triton's Backward Orbit
sections.content: Neptune's largest moon, Triton, is one of the coldest objects in the solar system at -235°C, yet it has active geysers that shoot nitrogen ice and dust into space. Uniquely, Triton orbits Neptune backward (retrograde), suggesting it was captured from the Kuiper Belt. This capture likely disrupted Neptune's original moon system, and Triton is slowly spiraling inward—in 3.6 billion years, it will be torn apart by tidal forces.

timeline.event: Neptune completes first orbit since discovery
